metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Applications of Paper as a support material in biomedical sciences: A Decadal review Decadal review 2

body_text.text: also been used to develop paper-based 3D cultures and scaffolds to test drugs, and monitor 1 cytotoxic effects in vitro cell microenvironments and also as implantable tissues. In this review, we 2 intend to enumerate the development in the field of µPADs, paper-based cell cultures, and paper-3 based scaffolds and their plethora of applications over the last decade. 4 1. Introduction: 1. Introduction: 1. Introduction: 1. Introduction: 5 Historically, paper has been used as a tool to record and preserve information (Authority, 2019), but 6 over time it has found its application in the field of Biomedical Sciences . Paper being 7 a cellulose-based substrate, has a long history to perform biomolecular assays. Due to its 8 affordability, wide availability, and its hydrophilic nature, it is considered to be one of the most 9
promising materials for the fabrication of paper-based biosensors (Martin & Synge, 1941 ). The first 10

paper-based device for the semi-quantitative detection of glucose in urine was demonstrated in 11 1956 that further developed into immunochromatographic paper-based lateral flow test strips, with 12 the well-known example of pregnancy test kits (Landmark, 2010) . Later on, George Whitesides 13

introduced the method of fabricating microchannels on paper for multiplex analyte detection based 14 on colorimetry; thus giving rise to microfluidic paper-based analytical devices or simply, µPAD 15 (Martinez, et al.., 2007) . A µPAD can be defined as a paper-based analytical device used to perform 16 biomolecular assays, consisting of a sample-loading zone and a testing zone with varying 17 architecture of channels concerning its application. Thin, light and flexible nature of cellulose paper 18 makes it an excellent raw material to fabricate µPAD with applications ranging from blood-plasma 19 separation to detecting viral, cardiac and oncological biomarkers (Yang, Forouzan, Brown, & 20 Shevkoplyas, 2011) (Wu, Xue, Hui, & Kang, 2014). These low-cost devices can be used in developing 21 economies in Asia and Africa, where deploying sophisticated detection devices like 22 spectrophotometers are not economically viable. Moreover, the population in these economies is 23 higher; thus increasing the chances of the prevalence of epidemics like Ebola and Severe Acute 24 Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in Africa and China, respectively. Hence, the development of low-cost 25 paper-based analytical devices can help in quarantining those infected by such viruses as well as 26 facilitate early detection of diseases and conditions like Hepatitis-C virus (HCV) infection and Venous 27 Thromboembolism (VTE). 28

However, µPADs on their own are not efficient enough to perform the biomolecular assay, hence 29 their surfaces are modified to increase the detection of an analyte as well as amplify the signal 30 generated. Surface modification is done using nanomaterial like carbon nanotubes (CNT), graphene 31 nanosheets, metal nanoparticles, metal oxide nanoparticles, and their nano-conjugates, which are 32 synthesized using a plethora of methods ( On the other hand, paper is also revolutionizing the field of Tissue engineering, viz. paper-based cell 37 cultures and scaffolds. For almost a century, cell cultures were being developed on surfaces of Petri 38 dishes and glass plates in the form of 2D monolayers and tests were performed on them. However, 39 they had major limitations as cell microenvironments were 3D. Hence scientists started to engineer 40 3D-substrates to make cell cultures. Eventually, they succeeded in doing so using artificial polymers; 41
but the polymers were difficult to fabricate and were mostly non-biodegradable. Thus, the focus 42

shifted to paper-based materials and the substrates developed so far, showed promising potential 43 (Simon, et al., 2016 ) (Boyce, et al., 2016) . Similarly, synthetic polymers were used to make scaffolds. 44

Fabrication of these scaffolds was neither convenient nor feasible, but now research is ongoing to 45 replace it with paper-based-scaffolds (Park, et al., 2014) , which are low-cost and can mimic the 1 biological Extra-Cellular-Matrix (ECM). The paper-based scaffolds can provide a valuable platform for 2 basic stem cell research to study material effects and also to perform drug test (Park, et al., 2014 ) 3 (Wang, et al., 2015 ) (Wang, et al., 2018) . Generally, for tissue engineering fibrous nature, porosity 4 and flexibility of scaffolds are desired and possessing all these characteristics paper has the potential 5

to replace conventional scaffolding materials like polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), glass fiber, chitosan, 6 which are difficult to fabricate and are not feasible for low-income economies. For the proper 7 proliferation of cells in vitro, a microenvironment that mimics the in vivo characteristics of the body 8 is necessary (Cramer, Larson, & Lockett, 2019) . However, the challenge with paper is that it is 2D in 9 structure, hence researchers stacked the cell-laden papers on top of one another to make the 3D 10 microenvironments. Using this technique, researchers developed "a beating heart on paper", which 11 was beating for about 3 months; and in another instance, researchers developed a 3D liver model on 12

paper scaffold which showed similar response, like in a real liver in vivo (Wang, et al., 2015 ) (Wang, 13 et al., 2018) . Similar to µPADs, paper substrate used in the fabrication of cultures and scaffolds were 14 surface modified to enhance cellular growth. 15

This review intends to enumerate the development in the field of µPADs, paper-based cell cultures, 16 and paper-based scaffolds over the last decade. We have explained their structure, composition, 17
surface modification, and functionality. Hopefully, this review will encourage more research in these 18
fields and the development of more commercially viable paper-based devices. Also, may this review 19 be helpful to the new-comers in this field and may demonstrate the importance of such low-cost 20

paper-based analytical devices and scaffolds. 21 membrane filtration and cross-flow filtration for blood plasma separation (Songjaroen, et al., 2012) . 31 However, these methods come with disadvantages like the requirement of external force for the 32 flow of substances through the microfluidic channel but paper can be used to make microfluidic 33 systems that can work without the requirement of such forces. The µPAD developed by Yang et al 34 used the principle of RBC agglutination induced by anti-bodies. The plasma separation zone in the 35 center was made functionalized by spotting anti-A, B onto it, and the reagents of the colorimetric 36 assay onto the test readout zones in the periphery. To perform the assay, a drop of whole blood was 37 placed at the plasma separation zone, which leads to agglutination of RBC and separation of plasma. 38 The plasma obtained using this process was significantly high to perform the colorimetric assay. 39 Similarly, a year later, Songjaroen et al developed a different method of separating blood plasma 40 from whole blood (Songjaroen, et al., 2012) . They fabricated a µPAD consisting of two types of 41

Paper, i.e. blood filter paper and patterned Whatman No.1 filter paper to separate blood plasma 42 from other components by agglutination of the components and penetration of plasma through the 43 paper by capillary action. By wax dipping method, various layers were incorporated onto the paper 44 for separation of particles greater than 2-3 mm including red cells and platelets from whole blood. 45

Once the plasma is separated from the other components of blood, biomarkers of interest can be 1 analyzed using various biomolecular reactions. In the following paragraphs, we have divided the 2 detection of biomarkers into blood-based and non-blood-based; i.e. biomarkers present in blood 3 and those present in other body fluids like saliva, tears, and urine. 4 2.1.1 Blood-based detection 5 In this method, biomarkers present in the blood are analyzed using µPAD. For example, in 2016, Hu 6 et al. developed a µPAD with combined blood serum extractor with dual-mode iron health tests: 7 fluorescent analysis for Fe3+ and colorimetric ELISA for ferritin, which is a blood protein containing 8
iron (Hu, et al., 2016) . The µPAD was fabricated by sequentially patterning the filter paper with in 9

situ growth of Carbon-Dots (CDs) and Au-Nano-Particles. For CDs rendered different reaction rates 10 for paper and consequently led to two distinguished regions on paper simultaneously: the 11 fluorescent CDs (F-CDs), for serum iron analysis and the non-fluorescent CDs (nF-CDs) for chemical 12 deposition of Au. The high triggering ability for blood coagulation was shown by the surface, which 13 enabled automatic and highly effective serum extraction on the µPAD. Patterning (CPP) to fabricate the multiple test zones on Nitro-Cellulose paper substrate; as NC is 28 highly flammable. Hence, the developed microfluidic paper-based immunoassay harnessed the 29 'irreplaceable' merits of paper to integrate the lengthy, costly, and segmented assays rapidly and 30
economically. Then, in 2016, Chen and Xinyu developed a much advance µPAD to detect HCV and 31

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) together in under 20 mins with high accuracy and sensitivity as 32 well as low Limit-Of-Detection (LOD) to existing sensors (Chen & Xinyu, 2016) . They claim to be the 1 first to integrate µPAD for low-cost diagnosis of HIV/HCV co-infection. It had eight electrochemical 2 immunosensors capable of carrying out "ELISAs in parallel and testing multiple serum samples for 3 both HIV and HCV antibody marker". Moreover, it could transmit the data to a host computer or 4 smartphone via wireless transmission. In another instance, Bedin et al. to develop a wax printed 5 MF1-based-µPAD for the detection of the dengue and Zika NS1 (Non-Structural) viral proteins in 6 blood plasma. The presence of glass fiber enables the separation of plasma from red blood cells 7 (Bedin, et al., 2017) . The test zone of the µPAD was functionalized by adding an anti-NS1 antibody. If 8 NS1 is present, it is captured by the anti-NS1 antibody and a blue band appears in the test. If NS1 is 9 absent, there is no signal. The µPAD take 4-6 min to analyze the sample and a smartphone 10 application is used to interpret the results. The µPAD performed better than a commercially 11

available Lateral-Flow-Assay (LFA), both in terms of Limit-Of-Detection (LOD) and of time-to-result. 12 2.1.1.2 Cardiac Biomarkers: 13 According to another article published by Economic Times India, Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) is 14 becoming a leading cause of death along with heart disease, Brain stroke and cancer (Akhter, 2016) . 15 It is an under-diagnosed disease among many and most common preventable cause of death in 16 India. VTE leads to long term complications like post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) and chronic 17 thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). PTS can cause swelling and pain in the affected 18 leg and CTEPH can cause the right side of the heart to work harder than normal owing to abnormal 19 high-blood pressure. In both the condition, early diagnosis is necessary. It can be achieved by 20 measuring the levels of thrombin or thrombin content in blood serum. The available methodologies 21
to measure thrombin levels require both time and technicians. Recently, Xue et al constructed a 22
Microfluidic paper-based photo-electrochemical device (µPECD) to detect thrombin at point-of-care 23

(POC) (Xue, et al., 2019) . µPECD employs the complete separation of the detection signal and 24 excitation source, thus, providing high sensitivity with a low background signal. The high sensitivity 25 in µPECD can be achieved by the production of large photocurrent signals; which was achieved by 26 incorporating Titanium Dioxide in the paper substrate, due to its good biocompatibility, 27 photoelectric activity, and chemical stability. Again to gain more sensitivity, aptamers were used, 28 instead of antibodies, due to their stability and reusability. To check its real-world feasibility, four 29 human serum samples were tested with the µPECD and ELISA. The results had no significant 30 differences, thus demonstrating the excellent potential practical application of µPECD. However, a 31

year cells, medical Imaging is used which is a non-invasive method involving the use of X-Rays or 43 radionuclides for imaging specific parts of the human body. Endoscopy is used as a diagnostic 44 method for Gastro-Intestinal Oncology related complications. It is used to detect lesions, facilitate 45 macroscopic classification of tumors and enable biopsy (Costa, 2016) . In a biopsy, a tissue sample is 46 taken out from the lump of cells, which might have been found by imaging tests or physical 1 examination and different cytological tests are done to examine the growth of 2 cancerous cells. 3
However, all the above-mentioned methods are tedious, time-consuming and need expert 4 assistance. Moreover, the methods are not efficient enough to detect cancer cells at an early stage. 5
In the case of imaging tests, it can find large groups of cancer cells but not single cancer cells or even 6 a small cluster of cells . Also, endoscopy, even though being a safe method to 7

visualize the colonic mucosa, however, the "sensitivity of the capsule endoscopy for detecting 8 colonic polyps, advanced adenomas, and colorectal cancer was relatively low" (Van Gossum, et al. device, which was tested for the detection of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and CEA as biomarkers of 30 hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and colorectal cancer (CRC), respectively (Draz, et al., 2018) . The 31 microchip comprised of three-layer hybrid substrates made of cellulose paper substrate assembled 32 with a transparent plastic sheet using double-sided adhesive. The fabrication process of the 33 microchip took <1h and leveraged the advantages of layer-by-layer assembly. The PPMC had 34 electrodes printed within the cellulose paper, which had better signal resolution compared to the 35 common protocol of screen-printing electrodes on the surface of the chip. The results showed a 36 good correlation between the expected and measured values with a maximum error of <7%. 37 2.1.2 Non-blood-based detection 38 In non-blood-based detection, biomarkers present in body fluids like, saliva, urine, or tear are used. 39 The advantage that the methods using non-blood-based biomarkers are the fact that there's no 40 need for any purification methods, unlike blood-based detection where blood plasma needs to be 41 separated from whole blood. Thus, rendering it better than blood-based methods. Nitrates are 42 compounds naturally occurring in the human body and some foods like green leafy vegetables (Kris, 43 2020). In the human body, nitrate after absorption in the upper gastrointestinal tract, it reaches the 44 salivary gland via blood circulation and is secreted in the oral cavity where the microflora partially 45 reduces it to nitrite (Eisenbrand, Spiegelhalder, & Preussmann, 1980) . In 2014, Bhakta et al 46 developed a µPAD for detection of nitrite in saliva, which used Griess reagent for detection, which 1 could indicate chances of developing periodontitis with clinical symptoms like gingival redness, 2 swelling, and bleeding of gums, as it is associated with the concentration of nitrite (NO 2 1-) which is an 3 antimicrobial agent produced from nitric oxide released by endothelial NO-synthases in saliva 4 (Bhakta, et al., 2014) . The selected prototype for the µPADs had a main channel with four identical 5 arms and four round "Testing zones", designed using black lines and shapes on a white background. 6 The dimensions of the finished µPADs (Fig 2) were 24 mm by 24 mm, with a 2 mm width for the 7 main channel and a 3 mm diameter for the testing zones. The sample was up taken on the µPAD 8 through capillary action and the solution was driven into the branched channels and the testing zone 9 of the µPAD. In an acidic medium and the presence of nitrite, the two components of the Griess 10 reagent led to the formation of a magenta azo compound, in the presence of nitrite. Later, to 11 maximize the color development, the acetic acid of the Griess reagent was replaced by 5% H3PO4. A 12 quick, easy, and inexpensive analytical method of quantifying nitrite levels in human saliva was 13 offered by the optimized configuration. According to the researchers, this methodology could aid 14
research leading to establish a definitive relationship between salivary nitrite levels and 15

periodontitis. In urine, other compounds such as Creatinine (CRN) and uric acid are also released by the body. 28 Creatinine is spontaneously produced in the metabolism of muscle contraction from creatine and 29 phosphocreatine and is excreted by the kidneys. It is an important clinical marker for renal function 30 since the rate of excretion of creatinine is relatively constant. Similar to this design developed by 31 Bhakta et al, Edwardo et al, constructed a µPAD and developed two optimized methods for the 32 simultaneous quantification of two biomarkers in urine, namely creatinine and uric acid, using Jaffe's 1 method and a Phenanthroline method respectively (Rossini, et al., 2017) . The proposed analytical 2 device can be used to evaluate renal function and help prevent kidney failure. The analytical device 3 used was 19 × 19 mm, with 4mm width for the main channel, 2 mm width for the arms, and 4 mm 4 diameters for the testing and uptake zones. Using a wax printer, the design was printed on a 5
Whatman No. 1 filter paper with wax toner following the description given by Carrilho et al (Carrilho, 6 Martinez, & Whitesides, 2009). 7

Then, in 2016, Gabriel et al. showed that tears can also be used for glucose and uric acid estimation. 8 They used Sensitive colorimetric detection for chitosan incorporated paper surface resulting in 9

better solid support to adsorb enzymes ensuring a more effective reactive area in the whole 10 detection zone (Gabriel EF, et al., 2016) . These devices were used for the quantitative analysis of 11 glucose and uric acid which yielded an accuracy at the range of 87 to 114%. The remarkable 12 improvements in analytical sensitivity allowed the colorimetric detection of glucose in human tear 13

samples. No statistical difference was found at a confidence level of 95%, in the performance of 14 chitosan-modified μPADs for the detection of glucose when compared to the analysis carried out by 15 the spectrophotometry technique, thus proving the analytical reliability for quantitative analysis. In 16 another instance, Jia et al developed a μPAD for direct detection of glucose from saliva (artificial) 17

using a smartphone-based colorimetric assay, having a LOD of 0.02mM (Jia, et al., 2018) . They 18 modified the cellulose fiber of the paper with Graphene-Oxide prohibiting any possible enzyme 19 cross-examination, and also enhanced reagent absorptivity, reactive efficiency, and homogeneity of 20 color distribution. They claimed it to be universally applicable as the modification of the μPAD with 21
Graphene-Oxide can be achieved without the use of any linker, binder or retention aid. Thus, the 22 developed device was disposable and could perform rapid and reliable analysis of samples, when 23

compared with other paper-based sensors, owing to automatic smartphone image analysis. Table 1  24 summarizes the above applications in chronological order. 25 (Tanaka, et al., 2014) . The material used in these techniques was synthetic 1 polymers which were limited and required complicated fabrication processes and expensive 2 instruments (Tanaka, et al., 2014) . To prepare cell culture scaffolds, smooth polymers are used, but 3

to develop such scaffolds with topographical features, time-consuming methods such as hot 4 embossing and soft lithography had to be used. One such example of the 3D microenvironment is 5 spheroids. Spheroids are hydrogel scaffolds that are widely used to assess therapeutic efficacies and 6

toxicities. These microenvironments mimicked the poorly vascularized tumor tissue due to the 7 presence of chemical gradients. These chemical gradients formed zones viz., necrotic cells at the 8 core, quiescent cells in the interior and proliferating cells along the exterior (Boyce, et al., 2017) . 9 However, spheroids had certain limitations: Firstly, histological sections had to be made to study 10 these spheroids; Secondly, they offered limited experimental control over the formed chemical 11 gradients; and lastly, only a small subset of cell lines are capable of forming aggregates. Hence, 12

paper-based-cultures (PBCs) emerged as a promising alternative to polymer-based-cultures. Fig 3  13 shows a pictorial representation of the different zones of cells in tumors, spheroids, and Cells-in-14
Gels-in-Paper. control oxygen and nutrient gradients in 3D and to analyze molecular and genetic responses" called 27

'Cells-in-Gels-in-Paper' or CiGiP (Derda, et al., 2009 ). Using the same technique, in 2011, a group 28 demonstrated that rapid generation and analysis of 3D cultures is achievable by stacking sheets of 29

paper that contain 96 cell-containing zones (Derda, et al., 2011) . Before this technique, the majority 30 of 3D cultures based on high throughput assays which were only able to detect the average behavior 31 of cells present in the culture. However, using CiGiP, it was easier to culture arrays of thin planar 1 sections of tissues, either alone or stacked to create complex tissue models and thus, it was simpler 2 to isolate cells from a specific region of the culture and analyze their behavior. This opened new 3 possibilities where paper can be used as a substrate-material to mimic cell microenvironments. binder. The sample P-4 was coated with an aqueous latex blend consisting of a 3:2 weight ratio of 33 low-Tg film-forming (''soft'') styrene-butadiene and high-Tg non-film-forming (''hard'') polystyrene. 34 It was found that the PDMS film had the lowest surface energy whereas the Polystyrene (PS) dish 35 had the highest surface energy. Thus, paper proved to be a better alternative to prepare 2D cell 36 cultures, too.

Other than using paper to make paper-based-cultures to monitor chemoresistance of cells or 4 metabolic responses; it has also be used to make 3D cell cultures that not only mimic the tissue 5 environment but also develop working implantable tissues. Moreover, they showed similar activity 6 and response to drugs and other chemicals. For instance, in 2014, Park et al. demonstrated the 7 feasibility of paper materials for stem cell culture, differentiation, and implantation to repair tissue 8 defects (Park, et al., 2014) . They developed a paper scaffold made of Weighing Paper (WP) which 9
significantly enhanced osteogenic differentiation and in vivo bone regeneration of human-Adipose-10

Derived-Stem-Cells (hADSCs). In their research, Papers laden with osteogenically differentiated 11 hADSCs and human endothelial cells, when stacked together led to vascularised bone formation in vivo. Fabricating such a paper-based scaffold was met with challenges as papers can be easily 1 damaged by heat or organic chemicals when applied to modify the surface. Hence, they used a 2 method called initiated-Chemical-Vapour-Deposition (iCVD), in which the conformal coating of 3 functional polymer films can be applied over the paper substrate without any damage. Similarly, in 4 2015, Petersen et al. investigated the applicability of single layer paper-based scaffolds for the three-5 dimensional (3D) growth and osteogenic differentiation of equine adipose-derived stem cells 6 (EADSC) and achieved a viable culture EADSC (Petersen, et al., 2015) . Likewise, Kim et al developed a 7
paper scaffold, whose surface was conformally modified with poly(styrene-co-maleic anhydride) 8
layer supported the prolonged culture of chondrocytes. It was versatile and allowed area-selective 9

cell seeding. When transplanted properly into a three-ring defect trachea in rabbits, it replaced the 10 native trachea without stenosis after 4 weeks and provided a tight seal without the need for sutures 11 (Kim, et al., 2015) . In the same year, Li Wang and his group claim to have made a 'heart on a paper'. 12

It was the first attempt to fabricate a paper-based-array for the culture, proliferation, and direct 13 differentiation of human-induced-Pluripotent-Stem-Cells (hiPSCs) into functional beating cardiac 14

tissue. The hiPSC-derived cardiac tissue was able to maintain a long-term spontaneous beating 15 activity of about 3 months (Wang, et al., 2015) . In another model, Yaqing Wang and his group developed a 3D liver model (Fig 6) , which was formed 3 by the co-cultures of human-induced-Hepatocytes (hiHEPs) and Human-Umbilical-Vein-Endothelial-4

Cells (HUVECs) on the paper scaffold. It was able to maintain a long-term stable morphology and 5 hepatic functions assessed by secretion of albumin, synthesis of urea and CYP450 gene expression 6 which is responsible for the oxidation of steroids, fatty acids, and xenobiotics, for 60 days. Also, the 7 3D culture showed hepatotoxic characteristics of well-known drugs like Acetaminophen (APAP) and 8

Pioglitazone (Wang, et al., 2018) . However, the devices were only able to give the user, a qualitative response; rather than a 8 quantitative one; i.e. a yes or no, rather than an estimation of the concentration of the analyte. 9

Microfluidic-Paper-based-Analytical-Device (µPAD) sensors bought a paradigm shift in the field of 10 biosensors and showed its potential to revolutionize the diagnosis (Bedin, et al., 2017 ) (Chen & 11 Dong, 2015) (Hu, et al., 2016) and therapeutics (Park, et al., 2014 ) (Kim, et al., 2015) sectors of 12

Biomedical Sciences. These sensors were not only able to give a colorimetric response but also give 13 an estimation of the concentration of the analyte. On the other hand, the paper has also found its 14 applications in developing paper- (Roy, et al., 2017) . In this review, we 1 examined the progress done in the last 10 years in both these technologies. 2 A major challenge with paper-based sensors is the composition of paper, which is mostly cellulose 3 and hemicellulose. It is inherently, a non-conducting material; hence paper was primarily used for 4 colorimetric tests. Hence, modification was done in the paper substrate using carbon nanotubes, 5 graphene nanosheets, metal nanoparticles, metal oxide nanoparticles, and their nano-conjugates, to 6 fabricate µPADs, like those of Electrochemical-µPAD (E-µPAD); thus improving the performance of 7
the sensor system (Kumar A. , Purohit, Maurya, Pandey, & Chandra, 2019). E-µPADs are being given 8
prime attention due to its ability to provide low cost, and precise estimation of target molecules 9

( initiated-Chemical-Vapour-Deposition (iCVDs). Also, these paper-based-sensors are sensitive to 29 temperature and humidity, as the detection zones are dependent on the temperature and relative 30 humidity of the environment (Morbioli, et al., 2017). Even though the rise in temperature improves 31 enzyme activity, they also evaporate the water from the spots faster and even denature enzymes. 32
The thermal stability can be increased by adsorption of enzymes on paper with conjunction with a 33 humidifier substance. 34

On the other hand, paper on its own is not an optimal material for culturing cells, as it lacks cell 35 adhesion moieties (Ng, et properties due to better surface morphology and higher porosity of ES-PCL/FP. PCL and paper 2 complemented each other, resulting in the highest metabolic and ALP activity. Also, these culture 3 systems must be disassembled before analysis, thus preventing the taking of measurements as 4 gradients formed. To this, a potential solution was developed Matthew et al to measure spatial and 5 temporal information about oxygen gradients, without disassembling the layers by using a 6 luminescent thin-film sensor (Boyce, et al., 2016) . Oxygen readily diffused into these films resulting 7
in changes in luminescence intensity with changes in the surrounding oxygen tension. 8

Lastly, a challenge that remains with paper-based scaffolds is that of imaging them to check cell 9 adhesions, proliferation or interaction with chemicals. Currently, such scaffolds are unfolded layer-10 by-layer and then imaged (Rodenhizer, et al., 2016 15 Paper has been used as supporting material in Biomedical Sciences and has shown immense 16 potential for the development of biosensors and scaffolding-material in the field of Biosensors and 17
Tissue Engineering, respectively. This literature review enumerated the applications of paper as a 18
supporting material over a decade and the research and development going on in the field of 19

Biomedical Sciences. Earlier, LFAs were used for diagnostic purposes but they gave only qualitative 20 results; but with further research paper-based devices were prepared which were able to give 21 qualitative as well as quantitative results. For diagnosis purposes using paper, various biomarkers 22

are considered, viz. viral proteins, metabolites viz. NO 3 , NO, Creatinine, Uric Acid which can be 23 detected using a µPAD. Moreover, paper has also been used for oncological diagnosis and prognosis 24 and proved to be efficient and easy to handle platform which gave an edge to cancer therapy. 25
Paper-based scaffolds have shown the immense capability to revolutionize the field of Tissue 26
engineering. It has been used to develop 'heart on a paper' and co-cultures of Liver cells where drug 27

testing showed promising results. The porous, and fibrous structure of paper enabled the transport 28 of nutrients and oxygen across the entire thickness of the paper, which thereby allows cellular 29 remodeling, proliferation, and differentiation of cells. The scaffolds developed were also used as an 30 implantable material on rabbits to replace a damaged trachea. However, out of the various 31 laboratory experiments and researches on µPADs, presented in this paper, none have found 32 commercial utility till now. Therefore, current and future researches need to be more market-33
oriented and be commercially viable to the masses. For that, the researchers have to overcome the 34 aforementioned challenges in the writing of the paper. 35

A future can be imagined in which people use a paper for diagnosing malicious diseases like cancer 36 at home in a simple kit, similar to the pregnancy test kits available in today's market. Moreover, 37 these devices will be cheap compared to the ones available now, and also easily disposable. On the 38 other hand, scaffolds used in Tissue Engineering can be used to test drugs using cells obtained from 39 the person requiring the drug. Drugs then will be patient-specific with negligible side effects. Also, 40 the development and deployment of these drugs to the market will be faster compared to today's 41 standards, as clinical trials could be performed faster using the cells from the patients. Thus, 42 reducing the development time and cost at the same time. 43

In conclusion, more research is required to access the change in analytical performance of the 1 various surface modification done on the paper substrate; the effect of temperature and other 2 environmental factors on the biosensors and non-enzymatic approaches must be explored in near 3 future. In the field of paper-based cultures and scaffolds, more research in cell viability in the 4 cultures and scaffolds must be done. Also, more research is required to compare the available 5 cytotoxic results done on 2D cell cultures with the new 3D cell cultures. 6 5. Conflicts of Interests: 7 No conflicts of interest.

FIGREF1.text: 9 2009). µPADs being a low-cost, non-invasive device can be a possible solution of detecting cancer 10 cells at an early stage. In 2014, Li et al. proposed a novel idea to detect oncogenes on target DNA on 11 a µPAD in vitro (Li, et al., 2014). They developed a porous Au-paper working electrode (Au-PWE) 12 which combined the porosity of paper and high conductivity of Au-nano-particles. The DNA sensor 13 showed tremendous specificity and also had a Limit-Of-Detection (LOD) as low as 8.5x10 -18 M. 14 Among the many antigens found in blood, Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can be used as 15 oncological biomarkers which is one the most widely used tumor marker in the clinical diagnosis of 16 colorectal, gastric, pancreatic and cervical carcinomas (Wang, et al., 2016). CEA levels directly 17 correspond to the stage of the tumor, the outcome of therapy and the prognosis. In 2016, Wang et 18 al developed a highly sensitive label-free paper-based electrochemical immunosensor employing a 19 screen-printed working electrode (SPWE) which was modified with graphene nanocomposite for 20 detection of CEA (Wang, et al., 2016). It demonstrated high efficiency and high sensitivity to the 21 samples it was tested against. Hence, it could provide a low-cost, sensitive Point-Of-Care diagnosis. 22 However, in 2017, Fan et al demonstrated the detection of Neuron-specific Enolase (NSE), a tumor 23 marker essential for monitoring effect and judging prognosis and diagnosis of small cell lung cancer 24 using a wireless POCT (Point-Of-Care-and-Testing) device comprising of a µPAD-based measuring 25 system (Fan, et al., 2017). The detection results of NSE were comparable to those measured by a 26 commercial electrochemical workstation. The data generated were hence, transmitted over to the 27 smartphone using Bluetooth and displayed in real-time. Again in 2018, Draz et al. developed a hybrid 28 Paper-Plastic Microchip (PPMC) for flexible and High-Performance Point-Of-Care (POC) Diagnostic 29

FIGREF2.text: ) is one of the metabolic wastes excreted out with urine(Nnate & Achi, 2016). The 19 detection of Nitrite (NO 2 1-) in urine analysis indicates some Urinary Tract Infection (UTI). It is due to 20 the conversion of nitrate to nitrite by gram-negative bacteria species like Escherichia coli, that Nitrite 21 is detected in urine analysis (Honrado & Dong, 2014). Using this concept, Chen and Dong developed 22 a peel-able µPAD attached to diaper for elderly patients, in which the urine sample is collected and 23 analyzed (Chen & Dong, 2015). The µPAD was made of filter paper with patterned wax with varying 24 concentrations of nitrite in eight segregated chemical reagent zones. A color change from white to 25 red-violet can be interpreted as a positive result. The intensity determines the concentration of 26 nitrite in the sample. 27

FIGREF3.text: Different zones of cells in a tumor, spheroids, and Cells-In-Gels-In-Paper. 17 2.2.1 Paper-based cultures: 18 Paper is a flexible, porous, low-cost, biocompatible biomaterial offered as a good choice for making 19 scaffolds (Park, et al., 2014). Due to the flexible nature of paper (Juvonen, et al., 2013), rapid and 20 profitable methods like roll to roll fabrication methods, like printing can be used for applying 21 chemicals (i.e. pharmaceutical ingredients or Toxic chemicals) in a controlled way and on a large 22 scale. Paper is composed of a cellulose network that acts like the Extra-Cellular-Matrix (ECM). Paper 23 is a 2D substrate, hence they are stacked on top of one another to create a 3D cell 24 microenvironment. In 2009, Derda et al developed a technique of "stacking and de-stacking layers of 25 paper impregnated with suspensions of cells in extracellular matrix hydrogel making it possible to 26

FIGREF4.text: et al developed a similar 96-well cell culture using CiGiP to examine the 5 cytotoxic effects of apoptosis inducer, Phenyl-Arsine-Oxide (PAO) and alkylating agent, Cyclo-6 Phospho-Amide (CPA) on human breast cancer cells (Deiss, et al., 2014). 7 Again in 2016, Simon et al developed a CiGiP 3D culture system to evaluate the metabolic response 8 of lung cancer cells to ionizing radiation within gradients of oxygen and other nutrients (Simon, et 9 al., 2016). These cell-laden scaffolds composed of the paper-plastic composite were placed in an 10 acrylic holder that enabled the exchange of fresh medium with the stack and generate a decreasing 11 gradient of oxygen. This arrangement mimicked the environment of a poorly-vascularized 12 environment of tissues like that of cancerous tumors: top stack was well-oxygenated whereas the 13 bottom stacks were experiencing hypoxic conditions and an increase in expression of HIF-1α and 14 CAIX. A similar model was used to study the chemoresistance of colorectal carcinoma cells (Boyce, et 15 al., 2017). Herein, stainless steel holders were used instead of an acrylic frame which ensured the 16 scaffolds were in conformal contact throughout the experiment. In 2018, Wang and his group 17 developed a multi-layer CiGiP to analyze tumor cell migration in 3D cultures (Wang, et al., 2018). To 18 monitor the progression of malignant tumors, the motility of the cells is measured. The developed 19 multi-layered 3D culture was seeded with prostate cancer cell in the middle layer and their 20 heterogeneous motility to the top and bottom layers was measured. Fig 4shows a timeline of the 21 development of CiGiP-based paper cultures. Research Labs, across the globe, uses Polystyrene (PS) 22 Dishes to prepare 2D cell cultures (Lerman, et al., 2018). 23 However, in 2013, Juvonen, et al. developed a 2-dimensional printed paper-based array, which was 24 successfully used for 2-D cell cultures and performed better than PS-dishes. Hydrophobic 25 polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) ink was used to print patterned structures on paper substrates for the 26 preparation of arrays used for two-dimensional cell culture and a lipophilic staining agent was 27preferred for cell imaging(Juvonen, et al., 2013). They considered four different types of coated 28paper substrates with characteristic roughness and surface energy for analyzing the substrate29   surface factors that influence the 2-D cell culture. The main components in the top coating layer of 30 the paper Substrates were: (P-1) precipitated calcium carbonate pigments and Latex binder; (P-2) a 31 mixture of two different kaolin pigments and Latex binder; and (P-3) kaolin pigments and a latex 32

FIGREF6.text: A year later, Whitesides et al. showed the use of 16 paper to guide the deposition of minerals like Calcium Phosphates by Osteoblasts. The porous and 17 fibrous structure of paper enables the transport of nutrients and oxygen across the entire thickness 18 of the paper, which thereby allows cellular remodeling, proliferation, and differentiation of cells 19 (Camci-Unal G, Laromaine A, Hong E, Derda R, Whitesides GM, 2016). 20 Timeline of the development of Organ-On-Paper. 2

FIGREF8.text: Kuldeep, Ananya, & Pranjal, 2018). Another challenge was that of amplifying the signals detected 10 using µPADs. Hence, in 2018 Wu et al. developed a µPAD with ultra-sensitive and high-throughput 11 detection of cancer biomarkers by introducing graphene onto the surface of the immune-device 12 which efficiently accelerated the electron transfer and enhanced the detection signal (Wu, Xue, Hui, 13 & Kang, 2014). Moreover, they provided a solution for accomplishing controlled radical 14 polymerization reaction, Activator Generated Electron Transfer for Atom Transfer Radical (AGET 15 ATRP), on a µPAD. 16 However, µPADs face other difficulties like complexity of cells migration from loading zone to testing 17 zone (Wu, Chueh-Yu, et al., 2014), lack of proper adhesion sites (Ng, et al., 2019) lack sensitivity to 18 amount of analytes and complexity in integration of functional reagents to substrates (Hu, et al., 19 2016).To tackle the problems different scientist groups proposed different solutions. To tackle the 20 problem of transporting suspensions of discrete objects like cells or microparticles laser 21 micromachined hybrid open/paper microfluidic chips were developed in which the liquid carrier was 22 transported in a Mylar microchannel but driven by a paper channel, with quantitative flow control 23 (Wu, Chueh-Yu, et al., 2014). Then, Ng et al. developed the ES-PCL/FP (Electro-spin-PCL over Filter 24 Paper) which showed incredible cell adhesion of human-Foetal-Osteoblastic cells (hFOB). Lack of 25 sensitivity was tackled by concentrating targets from a larger volume by speeding up intrinsic 26 thermodynamic partitioning in aqueous two-phase systems (Wu, Chueh-Yu, et al., 2014). Lastly, the 27 integration of functional groups or surface modification can be controlled by using techniques like 28

TABREF5.text: al., 2019). To develop the 'heart on paper', Li Wang and his group cultured 36 the hiPSCs on the paper array pre-coated with gelatine and Matrigel to facilitate the proper 37 proliferation of cells. Similarly, Yaqing Wang and his group pre-coated their paper-substrates with a 38 thin layer of 100 µg/ml rat tail collagen type I for better cell proliferation in the substrate. Hence, 39 optimum surface modification was required for proper cell adhesion and proliferation. In a recent 40 study, Ng et al compared three paper-substrate modification techniques, namely dip coating, 41 hydrogel modification, and electro-spinning over Filter Paper (FP) (Whatman grade 114) using 42 human foetal osteoblast (hFOB) (Ng, et al. 2019). Dip coating provided the least favorable cellular 43response, also resulted in reduced porosity; thus decreasing the number of anchoring spots for the 44 cells and limiting the overall cell penetration. In the case of hydrogels; the high molecular weight 45 polymers did not obstruct cell penetration and distribution within the scaffold. But, Electro-spin-Polycaprolactone coating over FP (ES-PCL/FP) proved to be superior in cell viability and mechanical 1

TABREF6.text: ). It is both laborious and can give conflicting 11 results. Again, most laboratory techniques are for testing and evaluating drug responses on 2D 12 cultures, hence new methods have to be invented to overcome the same (Cramer, Larson, & 13 Lockett, 2019) Hence, more research is required to improve paper-based sensors and scaffolds. 14 4.
